text:
We have found that customers
who establish and cultivate

a culture of security in their
organizations are much more

successful in moving workloads
to the cloud as part of their
digital transformation.

The question I've often received
from customers is, “How do I build

a culture of security at my own organization?”
And I typically answer it with

some examples of how we do it
here at Amazon Web Services (AWS).

Here are just a few. The culture
of security starts at the top.

Senior leadership must stress
the importance of security

frequently, whether it's within
an all-hands meeting or other
widely distributed communications.

If security is important
to the boss, it becomes important
to you.

At AWS, the AWS Chief Information
Security Officer (CISO) meets

every week with the AWS Chief
Executive Officer (CEO) for an
hour.

Operationally, this gives our
CEO deep visibility into AWS
security.

And culturally, it sets a tone
for the entire organization
that security is a top priority.

Security must be the path of least
resistance.

Organizations must make it easy
to observe and report any suspected

security anomalies, whether
they are real or perceived.

At AWS, we encourage employees
to raise a ticket with AWS security

operations whenever they suspect
something.

If you think you have a security
problem, then you do have a security
problem.

We'd much rather have someone
raise an issue and it be nothing
rather than the alternative.

Again, operationally,
the approach effectively

makes everyone a member of the
security team.

And culturally, it instills
a sense of ownership and responsibility,
regardless of role in the organization.

The security team are coaches
first and police second.

Security professionals
are there to share their expertise

and mitigate risk to the business,
not to build silos and be the
department of No.

At AWS, we developed a security-guardian
program where representatives

from each service team undergo
additional security training

so they can be security
experts within their respective

programs while having access
to subject matter experts
in AWS security, if needed.

This practice builds a strong
security partnership

between the development
teams and AWS security.

Operationally, this scales
the security team throughout
the organization.

And culturally, this empowers
service teams to own the security

of their respective services
and to move faster.

While I could give many more
examples, I hope this has given

you some ideas to try in your
own organization as you build
out your own culture of security.
